'''Clarence Garlow''' (February 27, 1911 – July 24, 1986)<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p78966|pure_url=yes}}|title=Clarence Garlow|author= |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=December 9, 2011}}</ref> was an [[United States|American]] [[rhythm and blues|R&B]], [[jump blues]], [[Texas blues]] and [[Cajun music|cajun]] guitarist, singer and songwriter.  He is best known for his recording of the song "[[Bon Ton Roula]]", which was a [[hit single]] on the [[United States|US]] ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs|R&B]] [[record chart|chart]] in 1950. One commentator noted the track as, "a rhythm and blues laced-zydeco song that helped introduce the Louisiana music form to a national audience."<ref>{{cite book
| first= Robert
| last= Santelli
| year= 2001
| title= The Big Book of Blues: a biographical encyclopedia
| edition= 1st
| publisher= [[Penguin Books]]
| location= [[London]], England
| isbn= 0-14-100145-3
| page= 177}}</ref>

==Biography==
He was born '''Clarence Joseph Garlow''' in [[Welsh, Louisiana|Welsh]], [[Jefferson Davis Parish, Louisiana]], [[United States]], although he relocated to [[Beaumont, Texas]] with his family whilst still a child.<ref name="Yee"/><ref name="Marion"/> After learning the rudiments of fiddle playing as a youngster, in his teenage years Garlow learned to play both the guitar and accordion.<ref name="Clayton">{{cite book
| first= Lawrence
| last= Clayton
| year= 2003
| title= The Roots of Texas Music
| edition= 1st
| publisher= [[Texas A&M University Press]]
| location= [[College Station, Texas]], United States
| isbn= 1-58544-221-6
| page= 207}}</ref><ref name="Marion"/> His guitar playing was influenced by [[T-Bone Walker]].<ref name="Centrohd">{{cite web |url=http://www.centrohd.com/bio/bio18/clarence_garlow_b.htm |title=Clarence Garlow |author= |work= |publisher=Centrohd.com |accessdate=December 9, 2011}}</ref> Initially working in several factories, Garlow first recorded for the small [[record label]], Macy's in [[Houston, Texas]], in 1949.<ref name="Marion">{{cite web |url=http://home.earthlink.net/~v1tiger/cgarlow.html |title="Bon Ton" - Clarence Garlow |author=J.C. Marion |date=2006 |work= |publisher=Home.earthlink.net |accessdate=December 9, 2011}}</ref> His debut release was "She's So Fine" b/w "Blues As You Like It", issued in January 1950.<ref name="Marion"/>

For the follow-up, Garlow recorded his own song "[[Bon Ton Roula]]", as a [[sixteen-bar blues]] with "an insistent, swirling rhumba rhythm".<ref>
{{Cite book  | last = Sandmel
  | first = Ben
  | authorlink =
  |author2=Oliver, Rick
  | title = Zydeco!
  | publisher = [[University Press of Mississippi]]
  | date = 1999
  | location =
  | page = 42
  | url =
  | doi =
  | id =
  | isbn = 978-1-57806-116-7}}
</ref>  "The song featured some of the same kind of broken [[Cajun French|Cajun]]-isms as [[Hank Williams]]'s "[[Jambalaya (On the Bayou)|Jambalaya]]".<ref>
{{Cite book
  | last = Vera
  | first = Billy
  | authorlink =
  | title = Louisiana Swamp Blues – liner notes
  | publisher = [[Capitol Records]] CDP 7243
  | date = 1996
  | location =
  | page = 8
  | url =
  | doi =
  | id =
  | isbn = }}
</ref> It became a hit in 1950, reaching #7 in the US ''Billboard'' R&B chart.<ref>
{{cite book
  | last = Whitburn
  | first = Joel
  | authorlink =
  | title = Top R&B Singles 1942-1988
  | publisher = Record Research, Inc
  | date = 1988
  | location =
  | page = 164
  | url =
  | doi =
  | id =
  | isbn = 0-89820-068-7}}
</ref>  The success of the [[Single (music)|single]] led to Garlow touring Texas and Louisiana. Feature Records then released another version of his hit titled "New Bon Ton Roula".  Lyric Records issued two further singles in 1951, but none charted.  The following year, Garlow opened the Bon Ton Drive-In in Beaumont. Relocating to [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], Garlow recorded his third version of "Bon Ton Roula", which was issued by [[Aladdin Records]] as "New Bon-Ton Roulay" in April 1953.<ref name="Marion"/><ref name="Rate">{{cite web |url=http://rateyourmusic.com/artist/clarence_bon_ton_garlow |title=Clarence "Bon Ton" Garlow |author= |work= |publisher=Rateyourmusic.com |accessdate=December 9, 2011}}</ref>

[[Flair Records]] provided the outlet for "Crawfishin'" b/w "Route 90" in November 1953, where he was billed on the label as "Bon Ton" Garlow.<ref name="Marion"/>

Garlow returned to Beaumont in late 1954, and toured with [[Clifton Chenier]], billed as the 'Two Crazy Frenchmen'.<ref name="Yee">{{cite web |url=http://www.yee.ch/winter/Band/winter_band_clarence_garlow.html |title=Clarence Garlow |author= |work= |publisher=Yee.ch |accessdate=December 9, 2011}}</ref> Garlow also undertook further recordings and had records released by Feature, Folk Star, and Goldband Records over the next few years.  None had success outside of his local area, and Garlow was by then working as a [[Disc jockey|DJ]] for the Beaumont based [[Radio broadcasting|radio station]], KJET, where he remained regularly fronting his "Bon Ton Show" until 1961. By this stage Garlow had ceased performing and recording, although his radio work, both in Beaumont and later in [[Orange, Texas]], continued until the early 1970s.<ref name="Marion"/> He supplemented his income by working as a [[Mail carrier|mailman]].<ref name="Centrohd"/> Garlow played infrequently on a local basis in the early 1980s, and appeared at the 1984 [[San Francisco Blues Festival]].

Garlow died in July 1986 in Beaumont, aged 75.<ref name="Marion"/>

His music has appeared on various [[compilation album]]s over the years.<ref name="Rate"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.discogs.com/artist/Clarence+Garlow |title=Clarence Garlow |author= |work= |publisher=Discogs.com |accessdate=December 9, 2011}}</ref> Amongst others, Garlow's songs have been [[cover version|covered]] by [[Lonnie Brooks]] ("Bon Ton Roulet" on ''Lone Star Shootout'') [[Johnny Winter]] ("Route 90" on ''Serious Business''), [[Gary Primich]] ("Route 90" on ''Mr. Freeze'') and [[Marcia Ball]] ("Crawfishin'" on ''Let Me Play With Your Poodle'').<ref>{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=clarence-garlow-p78966/songs/songs-composed-by|pure_url=yes}}|title=Clarence Garlow > Songs > Songs Composed By|publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=December 9, 2011}}</ref>
